title: A Mouse Model of MC903-Induced Atopic Dermatitis
procedures:
Materials Mice (C57BL/6J wild type, 6-10 weeks old) Isoflurane (Baxter, cat. no. 100190360400) MC903, calcipotriol, hydrate (Cayman Chemical, cat. no. 10009599) Ethyl alcohol (EtOH, ethanol) , pure, 190 proof (Millipore Sigma, cat. no. EX0290) 37°C mouse heating pad Precision-dial thickness gauge (Peacock, Ozaki Mfg. Co. Ltd, cat. no. GA-1) High-precision laboratory scale Additional reagents and equipment for Support Protocols 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-prot-0002]–5[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-prot-0006]. Days 0-14: Induce dermatitis 1. Anesthetize mice using 4% isoflurane in 2 L/min of oxygen for induction and 2% isoflurane in 0.4 L/min of oxygen for maintenance (Fig. 1C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0001] and D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0001]).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/4605d3db-490a-4f65-9318-546f75d65858/cpz1695-fig-0001-m.jpg

Figure 1 Topical application of MC903 induces atopic dermatitis-like skin inflammation in mice. C57BL/6J WT mice ears were topically treated with 1 nM MC903 or EtOH (as vehicle control) for 14 days. (A) Schematic of the treatment regimen. (B) Body weight was measured at each treatment day. (C) Mice were anesthetized using 4% of isoflurane in 2 L/min of oxygen. (D) Ear thickness was measured using a dial thickness gauge before the treatment. (E) Percent change in the ear skin thickness compared with Day 0 baseline values after MC903 or EtOH treatment. (F) Representative ear pictures on each treatment day. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation. Statistical significance was determined by (B) Student's t-test and (E) two-way analysis of variance. ****p < .0001; ns, non-significant. 2. Weigh mice using a high-precision laboratory scale and place animals on a 37°C mouse heating pad to maintain body temperature. Record weights over the course of treatment (Fig. 1B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0001]). 3. Measure both left and right ear thickness using a precision-dial thickness gauge under light anesthesia (Fig. 1D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0001], see Support Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-prot-0002]).

4. Topically, apply 1 nM MC903 in 100% absolute ethyl alcohol (EtOH) using a 2-20 µl pipette to both sides of each ear (10 μl on dorsal and ventral ear sides for a total volume of 20 μl per ear) on every treatment day according to the treatment regimen (Fig. 1A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0001]). Control mice are treated in parallel with the same volume of EtOH (as a vehicle control) only.
5. After the treatment, keep animals on a 37°C mouse heating pad to maintain constant body temperature during recovery, then return to cages.
6. Over the next 2 weeks (see treatment regimen, Fig. 1A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0001]), repeat measurements before topical application of MC903 or EtOH (steps 2-5). A total of 7 applications of MC903 or EtOH will be applied, with the final topical application on day 14.
Day 14: Itch assessment
7. On day 14, 24 hr before the experimental endpoint, record a video of the mice and quantify itch events via time-lapse videography. Determine and quantify itch events for 30 min (see Support Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-prot-0003]).
Day 15: Experimental endpoint
8. At the experimental endpoint (day 15), euthanize mice by CO2 asphyxiation, repeat measurements (step 3), and harvest ear skin tissues using sterile sharp scissors and forceps (Alam et al., 2020[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0001], Mac-Daniel, Buckwalter, Gueirard, & Ménard, 2016[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0009]). For ear draining lymph nodes, carefully cut the skin at the corresponding neck region and dissect the auricular lymph nodes (Alam et al., 2020[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0001], Mac-Daniel et al., 2016[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0009]) (see Support Protocols 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-prot-0004]–5[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-prot-0006]).

The topical application of MC903 can induce AD-like skin inflammation, and an increase in the thickening of ear skin is considered a surrogate marker for skin inflammation (Alam et al., 2020[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0001], Naidoo et al., 2018[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0011], Moosbrugger-Martinz et al., 2017[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0010]). The time course of ear skin inflammation can be monitored by measuring the ear skin thickness with a dial thickness gauge (Alam et al., 2020[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0001], Naidoo et al., 2018[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0011], Xie et al., 2021[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0012]).
Materials
70% (v/v) ethanol
Precision-dial thickness gauge (Peacock, Ozaki Mfg. Co. Ltd, cat. no. GA-1)
1. Thoroughly wipe the dial thickness gauge with 70% ethanol. Place anesthetized animals on a 37°C mouse heating pad to maintain constant body temperature (see Basic Protocol[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-prot-0001]). Measure and record both the right and left ear skin thickness with a dial thickness gauge (Fig. 1D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0001]).
It is critical to measure the same skin areas on each treatment day. Measure the thickness of ear skin gently with little-to-no compression. After each measurement, wipe the dial thickness gauge with 70% ethanol to avoid cross-contamination of MC903 and EtOH-treated ears.
2. On each treatment day, repeat measurements before the MC903 or EtOH treatment.
3. Calculate and plot the percent increase in skin thickness compared with day 0 baseline values (Fig. 1E[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0001]).

Itching is one of the hallmarks of AD, and itch-evoked scratching increases because of the MC903 treatment (Alam et al., 2020[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0001], Naidoo et al., 2018[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0011]). Itch frequency is determined and quantified on a recorded video captured at 24 hr before the experimental endpoint, for a period of 30 min. Materials Microisolator cage type II Video recorder 1. On day 14, place mice in a clear Microisolator type II cage (Fig. 2A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0002]). Record a video via time-lapse videography and quantify itch events for 30 min (Fig. 2B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0002]). An itching event is defined as a deliberate scratching activity directed at the treated skin by either the front or hind paws. This pathophysiology measurement was obtained from the video observation of the relevant treatment groups 24 hr before the experimental endpoint, as described previously (Alam et al., 2020[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0001], Lee et al., 2015[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0006], Naidoo et al., 2018[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0011])

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/5f7ae94a-1828-4b57-a054-c3d79d60d560/cpz1695-fig-0002-m.jpg

Figure 2 MC903 induces itch-evoked scratching in C57BL/6J WT mice. (A) Mouse video is recorded in the microisolator cage 24 hr before (day 14) the experimental endpoint. (B) Ear itching frequency per 30 min. Results are expressed as mean ± standard deviation. Statistical significance was determined by Student's t-test. *p < .05.

Materials RPMI 1640 medium, no glutamine (Gibco, cat. no. 21870076) FBS (Sigma-Aldrich, cat. no. C8056) R-10 medium (see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-rec-0004]) Phosphate buffered saline (PBS), sterile (Sigma-Aldrich, cat. no. D8537) 70% (v/v) ethanol 5-ml flat-bottom tubes (Techno Plas, cat. no. P5016SU) 1.5-ml Eppendorf tubes Needles, 0.5 × 16 mm Forceps, sterile, surgical Scissors, sterile, surgical Ice bucket 1. Prepare 5-ml flat-bottom tubes; add 2 ml of R-10 medium into each tube for skin samples. Prepare 1.5-ml Eppendorf tubes; add 1 ml of PBS per tube for ear draining lymph nodes. 2. At the experimental endpoint, euthanize mice by CO2 asphyxiation and place them on a dissecting board. Extend the mouse on its back with the limbs spread and fixed with needles in the four paws. 3. Wet fur and the corresponding neck region with 70% ethanol to avoid possible contamination. 4. Harvest one ear using sterile sharp scissors and forceps and separate the dorsal and ventral layers using two forceps, starting at the cut edge (Fig. 3C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0003]). Place them into a 5-ml flat-bottom tube containing 2 ml of R-10 medium; make sure both tissues are completely immersed in the medium. Place them on ice until further processing. To get a high yield of the number of cells of interest, pool both ears from the same mouse.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/be2cc01d-58dc-4945-ad53-7196bc557134/cpz1695-fig-0003-m.jpg

Figure 3

Dissection of ear skin and ear draining lymph nodes and histological analysis. (A) Representative picture showing the dissection of ear draining auricular lymph nodes. (B) Representative picture of ear draining lymph nodes at the endpoint, mouse treated with MC903 or ETOH. (C) Ear skin split into dorsal and ventral layers using two forceps, starting at the cut edge. (D) Representative ear sections were stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Original magnification = × 20, scale bar = 200 μm. (E and F) Epidermal and dermal thickening were measured in tissue sections by ImageJ software (National Institutes of Health). Each data point represents an individual ear or mouse, and n = 5 mice in each group. Results are expressed as mean ± standard deviation. Statistical significance was determined by Student's t-test. **p < .01, ***p < .001.
5. Using forceps and scissors, carefully cut the skin at the corresponding neck region and dissect the ear draining auricular lymph nodes (Fig. 3A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0003]). Place the lymph nodes into a 1.5-ml Eppendorf tube containing 1 ml of PBS, store on ice until further processing.

An important characteristic of the MC903-induced atopic dermatitis mouse model is the ability to recapitulate the structural changes associated with AD skin inflammation, including acanthosis, thickening of the dermis, parakeratosis, presence of spongiosis, and inflammatory lymphocyte infiltrates in the dermis (Alam et al., 2020[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0001], Li et al., 2006[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0008], Moosbrugger-Martinz et al., 2017[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0010]) (Fig. 3D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0003], E[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0003], and F[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0003]).
Materials
10% neutral buffered formalin
Hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) solution
Forceps, sterile, surgical
Scissors, sterile, surgical
Microscope slides
Aperio ImageScope software
ImageJ software (National Institutes of Health)
Additional reagents and equipment for standard methods of sectioning fixed tissue and staining with H&E (Moosbrugger-Martinz et al., 2017[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0010]).
1. After sacrificing animals by CO2 asphyxiation, excise the tissue of one ear using sterile forceps and scissors. Fix it in 10% neutral buffered formalin for 24 hr.
2. Embed one ear in paraffin, cut three 4-μm sections with a microtome, place sections on microscope slides and stain with H&E according to standard procedures (Moosbrugger-Martinz et al., 2017[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0010]).
H&E-stained ear sections are used to evaluate the structural changes associated with AD phenotypes, including epidermal hyperplasia, thickening of the dermis, parakeratosis, spongiosis, and dermal inflammatory immune cells infiltrates mostly consisting of lymphocytes, macrophages, eosinophils and neutrophils (Alam et al., 2020[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0001], Naidoo et al., 2018[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0011], Xie et al., 2021[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-bib-0012]).
3. Scan and capture images of H&E stained tissue slides at 20× magnification using the Aperio ImageScope software.
4. Measure epidermal and dermal thickness at three separate sites in the field of view on each tissue section using ImageJ software.
5. Calculate and plot the average of the collected data (Fig. 3E[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0003] and F[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-fig-0003]).

Materials
RPMI 1640 medium, no glutamine (Gibco, cat. no. 21870076)
FBS (Sigma-Aldrich, cat. no. C8056)
R-10 medium (see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-rec-0004])
Collagenase, type IV (Gibco, cat. no. 17104-019)
DNase I, grade II, from bovine pancreas (Roche, cat. no. 10104159001)
2× digestion medium (see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-rec-0002])
0.5 M EDTA (Invitrogen, cat. no. 15575020)
Buffer 1 (see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-rec-0001])
Phosphate buffered saline (PBS), sterile (Sigma-Aldrich, cat. no. D8537)
FACS buffer (see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.695#cpz1695-rec-0003])
Scissors, sterile, surgical
5-ml flat-bottom tubes (Techno Plas, cat. no. P5016SU)
Ice bucket
50-ml conical tubes
Disposable nylon cell strainers (mesh, size 70 μm)
1-ml syringe
1-ml pipette and tips
Shaker-incubator
Single-cell suspension from ear skin
1. Chop ear leaflets into fine pieces with sharp scissors to facilitate tissue digestion inside the 5-ml flat-bottom tube containing 2 ml of R-10 medium.
2. After mechanical disruption of ear leaflets into fine pieces, add 2 ml of 2× digestion medium into each tube and incubate in a thermo-shaker incubator at 37°C for 20 min under 100 rpm agitation.
Strictly maintain the digestion time and do not over-digest the tissue.
3. Add 1 ml of Buffer 1 into each tube to neutralize enzyme (collagenase IV and DNase I) activity. Perform the following steps on ice.
4. Prepare a single-cell suspension by filtering all ear tissue fragments and solution into a 50-ml falcon tube containing 5 ml of Buffer 1 through a 70-μm cell strainer and dissociating the remaining tissue fragments using a syringe plunger. Press the syringe plunger in circular motions against the strainer until all that remains is white connective tissue.
Cut a 1-ml pipette tip approximately 2-3 mm from the tip end to enlarge the orifice. Use this to collect the ear tissue-containing medium.

5. Rinse the strainers with 5 ml of R-10 medium to ensure all cells are collected. Centrifuge the tube for 5 min at 400 × g at 4°C and then discard the supernatant.
6. Wash the cell pellet with 10 ml of FACS buffer, centrifuge for 5 min at 400 × g at 4°C and then discard the supernatant.
7. Resuspend the cell pellet in FACS buffer, keep the tube on ice for antibody staining and flow cytometry analysis.
Single-cell suspension from lymph nodes
8. Mechanically disrupt and dissociate lymph nodes using the flat end of a 1 ml syringe plunger. Press the syringe plunger in circular motions against the 70 μm cell strainer until all that remains is white connective tissues.
9. Rinse the cell strainer with 5 ml of FACS buffer to ensure all cells are collected and centrifuge for 5 min at 400 × g at 4°C.
10. Discard the supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet in FACS buffer, keep the tube on ice for antibody staining and flow cytometry analysis.
